title: SoftBank takes control of WeWork as Adam Neumann pockets $185m payoff
text:
WeWork's ousted founder Adam Neumann will be paid $185m (£143m) as part of a deal to leave the company after the office space firm in a rescue from SoftBank.

The business decided on Tuesday to accept funding from SoftBank that cut its valuation to just $8bn and removed Mr Neumann as chairman.

As part of the deal, he relinquished his voting shares in the firm and his board seat.

Mr Neumann will also sell $1bn of stock to SoftBank and be given $500m of credit, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The $10bn (£7.7bn) financing deal offered by the Japanese conglomerate will stop the firm running out of cash next month but handed SoftBank about 80pc of the business.

A rival debt package offered by JPMorgan was rejected by WeWork’s board.

WeWork's new co-chief executives are planning to lay off at least 2,000 employees. The layoffs have been delayed from earlier this month, however, because the company struggled to afford the severance costs, according to reports.

The funding from SoftBank marks a major fall from grace for WeWork, once a darling of Silicon Valley and valued at as much as $47bn earlier this year.

The company, which rents out office space, abandoned its high-profile plans to list its shares after investors questioned its large losses, the sustainability of its business model and its governance.
